Simply charming! One of the best films of Woody Allen. The film is not just the sensitive and romantic story of Cecilia but also introduces its viewer on a fantastic journey and a love letter to cinema. Mia Farrow in one of his best performances. An exciting, fleeting and touching screenplay written by Woody genius and one of its strongest direction. The film also deals with the relationship between the real world and the world of movies, mixing comedy with drama, romance with adventure, showing that it is better to live in the movies than live in real life. Wise, humorous and exciting, Woody one more time take us to an incredibly journey of love, life and illusion.

What if a movie character could get out of the screen? In the hands of Woody Allen, this is the result. A classy and funny story with clever dialogue that puts a smile to your face. Here, the fictional world and the real world collide while touching some interesting themes. The soundtrack is great and, along with the art direction, it succeedes to create a nostalgic atmosphere. This portrayal of cinema as an escape from reality is done with charm and I really enjoyed it.
One of Allen's best, Mia Farrow delivers a stunning performance.
Its Reality Vs The Movies in this Woody's ageless masterpiece..

Woody Allen's three time/identity travel/escapist fantasy films are this one, ZELIG and MIDNIGHT IN PARIS. 
I'm a sucker for this movie, no matter how cheesey some of the jokes can get. Mia Farrow is at her most adorably naive, and one can't help but root for her character. Jeff Daniels is also adorably naive with his two characters, and it's fascinating how polar opposite they are, yet how Farrow has excellent chemistry with both of them. I can buy their chemistry, and I really feel for their characters in their sad situations. This is a sorely underrated Woody Allen film (as well as a romantic comedy film); more people need to see this. If you love intelligent rom-coms without all that Jessica Alba crap or are a Woody Allen film buff like me, give this a rent. Just make sure you don't fall in love with any characters stepping out of your screen.

3.5/4.0

Woody Allen's ode to cinema is a beautiful yet heartbreaking piece of work set in depression-era New Jersey and centering on Cecelia (Mia Farrow), a naïve waitress and unhappy housewife whose only escape from her wretched existence with her abusive husband (Danny Aiello) is going to the cinema. Her latest obsession is a film called "The Purple Rose of Cairo" about archaeologist Tom Baxter (Jeff Daniels in his first film role) who is doing work in Cairo and gets invited by a Manhattan socialitecouple while vacationing in Egypt. After repeated viewings at the cinema, Tom emerges from the screen and romances her. Things are complicated when similar happenings across the country force the actor playing Baxter, Gil Shepherd, to fly to NJ starting a very unusual love triangle. 

The plot may seem silly for some but the movie is an excellent depiction of the idea of film as escapism with Farrow perfectly cast in the lead role that conveys such message (although she has been cast in similar vulnerable roles before). The ending is heart-rending but the movie just engaging with a perfect mix between color and B&W vignettes (on-screen happenings). Nominated for One Oscar: Original Screenplay.
The idea behind it is sweet and joyful to watch although it doesn't reach the standards of other romantic fantasy films.

Fascinating!

Which is more real; Movies or Real Life? Which of them would you prefer?
A simple, yet beautiful fantasy comedy from Woody Allen. He does manage, however, to add his signature cynicism at the end of the picture.
At just over 80s minutes, its ironic disregard of narrative convention masks a poignant message on the bitter truths about Hollywood.

A magical exploration of illusion and reality with love as the gravitational pull that binds the two worlds together that are different in a sense but similar in essence. The Purple Rose of Cairo is a timeless masterpiece.
Brilliant, melancholy, sweet, special, and profound.
An odd concept. Seemed like it could end up being dumb but instead it was charming. Great dialogue. Woody Allen is such a good writer.

Classic and classy Woody Allen. Tom Baxter, an adventurous movie character steps off the screen to woo Cecilia, a starry-eyed, Depression-era waitress and cinephile, but the character's portrayer, Gil Shepherd, a smooth, somewhat megalomaniacal rising star, is called in to counter-woo Cecilia so that the show can go on. 

Woody's escapist fantasia is blissful yet tragic, blurring the lines between reality and make-believe, the haves and the have-nots, and love and truth.

It was nice to see young, wispy Dianne Wiest and bug-eyed Glenne Headley as slinky prostitutes. After watching so much cantankerous old Jeff Daniels on "The Newsroom," bright-eyed bushy-tailed young Jeff Daniels is a remarkable palate cleanser, with a great singing voice to boot! Mia Farrow is, of course, charismatic and vibrant with her delicate voice and damselly beauty. 

The last scene of her, dejected by the wretched realities of her life yet still utterly captivated by Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers in "Top Hat," is just the most indelible final image in Woody's canon.
No other movie comes to mind which is as much about the movie-experience as this one.It's a pity it isn't funnier.
A simple comedy about the magical escapism from reality that cinema allows set in depression-era America.

It plays out like a dream; it makes you unsure if you're awake. The characters are amazingly well written, while the satirical elements are ingenious: in a world were fiction has become reality, people are more concerned on how it will affect their businesses, career reputations, and daily lives. A great film.

Typical Woody Allen fantasia in his usual quirky style and a love letter to the golden age of cinema.
Mia Farrow plays a bored housewife to an abusive husband (Danny Aiello) in depression era New Jersey who goes to the cinema to watch "The Purple Rose Of Cairo".
On one of her repeat viewings, one of the characters (Jeff Daniels) escapes from the screen in order to romance her, leaving the film in limbo, much to the chagrin of the other patrons.
There's some good dialogue and the chemistry between Daniels & Farrow is excellent. The ending was a bit of a let down but I'd still put this amongst Allen's better movies.

Vintage escapism.  So this is about a young woman (Mia Farrow) who has it rough.  She is working a low-end waitress job, her husband is an abusive deadbeat, and everything is looking bleak.  On one particularly down day, she spends her time in a movie theater, watching the same picture, The Purple Rose of Cairo, over and over again.  Tom Baxter (Jeff Daniels), the dashing character in the movie, takes notice of her, and literally comes off the screen to sweep her off her feet.  This movie is chock-full of fantastic ideas, and it is made of that movie magic that will both break your heart and win you over with a smile.  The core concept itself is fantastic, and it is so charming, it is just infectious.  This is from Woody Allen, who is actually a much better fantasy director than people give him credit for, and that is because this is not fantasy in the traditional sense; between this and Midnight in Paris, he has all the credentials you need to know about, and he has brilliant ideas that he just runs with.  While I would praise this because I never at any point knew how it would play out, one criticism I have to make is that it all ends on a super cynical note that feels contradictory to the rest of the film's upbeat tone... but at the same, because it does that, it does make it extremely memorable, so it's a double-edged sword.  This was meta before meta was a word, a great throwback to Sherlock Jr., and one for cinema lovers.

An absolute charmer! One of Woody Allen's best, to be sure. Certainly one of his best from the 80's.  How cool is it to have a film-obsessed character interact with film characters, fall in love with them, and then fall in love with the actor playing the character? So fun and imaginative! The lines between reality and fiction get blurred to the point where you ask yourself which is the ideal. And the answer is never apparent. The ending is completely unexpected and yet perfect. One of Mia Farrow's best roles of her career. Sublime.

classic woody allen staple, he sometimes does fantasy, like midnight in paris, and it works, its definitely enjoyable, farrow daniels and aiello are all solid, its a pretty creative concept, just shows that woody can work at all levels of seriousness well
A charming & original romantic comedy that blurs reality & cinema. I have rarely related to a character more than to Mia Farrow's.

A fantastic and whimsical film.  Only Woody Allan could take an abstract premise like this and completely run with it.  The funniest moments come from all the logical extensions of such an illogical plot.  Half a star off for the ending not being more satisfying, but I do get the point.  This is really about Mia's character's â" and the country's â" love affair with the movies during the Great Depression.  I do think Allan invested us a little too much in the romance for this to end the way it does, but it's still strangely fitting.  People are right to compare this to Midnight In Paris, my personal favorite Woody Allan film.

'The Purple Rose of Cairo' is such a cute, short and honest film, and it works because Woody Allen sticks with its concept all the way through, not opting out for the sake of realism. It has such a fantastical charm about it that you'll find it hard not to smile, and Mia Farrow and Jeff Daniels are both just so innocent and whimsical in their roles that they make one of the great movie romances. 'The Purple Rose of Cairo' ends on a serious note that might seem depressing at first, but it's actually quite optimistic when you think about it.

This might be my favorite romantic comedy. I wish movies today were this original and clever. Then again, Woody Allen has perfected this genre so if anyone can do it properly, it's him. I highly recommend this film, especially if you appreciate going to the movies and the magic that is created when you lose yourself while watching the silver screen. Directors who are making romantic comedies now might as well stop. The bar is set too high.

"The Purple Rose of Cairo," is a magical romantic tale of a fictional character coming out of the silver screen and falling for a "real' woman. Jeff Daniels is in top form and very convincingly plays two different characters. This film is imaginative, unique and it never takes itself too seriously. Woody Allen wrote and directed yet another fine film.

Woody Allen wrote and directed this wonderful film about film, starring Mia Farrow as a poor woman during the depression who really loves the cinema, so much so that a minor character in the film she keeps going to see notices her and leaves the film to be with her.  It's funny, charming and a little sad...it has it all.  Fans of Woody Allen or cinema in general will definitely be pleased.  I enjoyed it immensely.

"The Purple Rose of Cairo" is the greatest film ever made about the reason why we watch movies and go to theaters. If you have not heard of it, the story is quite memorable. It's the great depression, Cecelia has an abusive husband, and works a painfully tiring job. Her only escape is cinema where she falls in love with the characters, the songs, and watches the same movies repeatedly. When she sees "The Purple Rose of Cairo" for another time, the film's main character, Tom Baxter, comes off the screen and falls in love with her. At the same time, the actor of the character, Gil Shepard, tries to get Tom Baxter back to the screen but falls in love with Cecelia. The strong point of the film is the writing which has some of the best dialogue of cinematic history, but an interesting plot as well. Woody Allen does not just rely on the premise but continues to surprise us repeatedly. We watch movies to forget about our troubled lives.   To meet characters who are more interesting than reality. However, film itself is an illusion; a collection of pictures played at 24 frames per second. The humor is undeniably genius. For instance, Mia Farrow upon meeting Tom Baxter says "I just met a wonderful new man. He's fictional but you can't have everything." "The Purple Rose of Cairo" is Woody Allen's best comedy film and also the greatest film that shows why we love movies. A showcase of brilliant and inventive writing filled with instantly quotable funny dialogue, and a daring ending for all feel-good movies.
The whole movie was pretty surrealist and in the end the shock of realism seemed cruel and out of place for me.
a timeless film from a master
another beautiful film from the mind of a genius.

Maybe the most Un-Woody Allen, Woody Allen Film, I have ever seen. For starters he isn't in it, and the lead, Mia Farrow isn't the neurotic lead Allen's films tend to have.

She's actually quite adorable. And he and Daniels are pretty great together.

The story of Daniels' movie character coming out of the movie and wanting to stay in the REAL world with her was quite cute, but I found the best stuff to be the rest of the movie cast not knowing how to move on without one of the film's stars, so they basically spend the 'movie' sitting talking to the audience who paid to see the real movie itself.

Daniels also plays the actor that played the character in the REAL world, but his Daniels is kind of a douche and does things for selfish reasons.

Both roles are good, and in the end, you really do feel for Farrow. Stuck with a man that doesn't respect her and no job, did she have to go back to that life.

I started wondering if any of this film even happened to begin with. Maybe it was all in her head while she was watching the movie for the fifth time. After all, isn't that why we go to the movies? To escape into worlds that cannot exist in our own lives?
The Purple Rose of Cairo is an eccentric and as well as a heavyhearted look on love and Woody Allen's perfect ode to the classic films of the '30s.

Chaotic and erratic in the truest Allen way, "The Purple Rose of Cairo" is perfectly lovable in its quirky storytelling and apparently aimless plot devices.

The story is set in a small sleepy American town during the 1930's. Mia Farrow skillfully portrays Cecelia, a woman living an unhappy life inhabited by an abusive marriage and a joyless job. Cecelia's only comfort is the magic offered by the movie theater where she sees her favorite escapist comedies time and again. Then, one night, a character of the movie "The Purple Rose of Cairo" addresses Cecelia directly. The romantic protagonist then proceeds to walk out of the screen into the real world. A peculiar love story is born.

This movie is often frustrating in its utter silliness, but it does contain the very kind of romantic movie magic Allen is obviously playing homage to. The writing is sharp, the dialog witty and Allen's familiar feminist themes are again in the focus.

This is about as typical a Woody Allen flick as you can find and as such doubtlessly splits opinions. But its a beautiful ode to the power of cinema and reminds us that some of the most difficult problems in our real lives can indeed sometimes be solved through an escape into the safe world of fiction.

Woody Allen's The Purple Rose of Cairo has a highly creative and intelligent idea behind it. It wasn't just a simple the screen comes to life story, the witty dialogue made this far superior to a plain story. I feel the first half really did express and let this creativity flow. The second half which is more romantic was less down my alley. After about 45 minutes I became more and more out of tune with the film. Which is unfortunate since I was highly involved at first.

 Mia Farrow is once again a great actress, and is sexy. In fact I'd watch the film just for her. This is one of Woodys films that he doesn't star in as well as direct/write. I think it would've been a good idea to have him play the director of "The Purple Rose of Cairo", but that didn't happen so after 28 years nothing you can do. It was a feel good movie, but unfortunately didn't have enough ideas to keep it running.

3 stars

The Purple Rose of Cairo is another funny and poignant film from Woody Allen with yet another brilliantly clever script and even a story that is a poignant and curious look at film obsession, extreme method acting and an era of cinema where films came and went like footsteps. Though short in time, it is a decent period piece, and a bittersweet metafictitious romance movie about movies.

Woody Allen's The Purple Rose of Cairo is a fresh and creative idea that celebrates the very idea of film escapism. A poor woman living in New Jersey named Cecilia goes to the movies every week to escape from her hectic job as a waitress, when one day, one of the characters from the film "notices" she appeared at the theater to see his film five times. He steps off the screen and goes with her into the real world. It's a cool concept, and it's done with heart and a clear love for movies. Despite this movie being filmed in 1985, it seems like Woody Allen directed the actors in such a way to make them act like they were in a movie from the 30's (which is when the film takes place). So it seems like you're watching a movie that is much older than it actually is, which is interesting but comedic at the same time. When the fictional movie character fights Cecilia's husband, it's clear that Allen was tributing the now cheesy style of old black and white films. The ending further capitalizes on the idea of people escaping to the movies when things get bad, or when we make bad decisions. Like alcoholics drink alcohol to forget their problems, as drug addicts do drugs, Cecilia (along with the normal people in society) uses movie theaters as an escape- and what a beautiful escape it is.
it's like the old version of "midnight in Paris", ouch reality bites
A brilliant fantasy for cinema.
Delightfully original.
As rare and as curious as if there is actually a purple rose in Cairo. Enchanting and surreal but still very loyal to reality.
Remains one of Allen's most sublime achievements.
Good, sweet, funny movie with a  sad ending.  Some funny, existential humor.  Highly recommended for movie and fiction fans!
Hilarious, clever, Woody Allen is too amazing.
Solid movie and a wonderful statement on most of Hollywood. I love Daniels in this movie (both roles!). A worthy Allen flick.

Charming and often delightful movie with a dark undercurrent that eventually surfaces. A woman's dreams are shaped and then fulfilled by movies, then destroyed by Hollywood, then her pain assuaged again by movies. Definitely a tension between the views of the product and the producers.
In 1930s New Jersey, a movie character walks off the screen and into the real world.
Outstanding Allen-esque tribute for old times cinema and it`s classics.
It was a neat movie, with a terrible ending.

I love it when Woody Allen plays in the realm of fantasy, especially here when that fantasy involves the cinema. Its funny that I'd never conceived of the idea of a film character leaping off of the screen and into the real world before but Allen has proved what a cute and charming idea it can be. And of course the theme of making your own decisions over pre-written destiny is as potent as always.
This film is at its best though when dealing with the remaining film characters on screen trying to figure out what to do next and communicating with the audience outside. The rest of the film is cute but I can't help but think could have soared higher with someone other than Mia Farrow in the lead role.
Absolutely magical love letter to the cinema. The performances, the story, the writing, the direction, all top notch. Filled my heart from beginning to end, one of Woody's best, if not his best.
So surprising, funny, sweet and true that it becomes one of Allen's best.

Man, they just don't make this kind of movie any more.  Striking that delicate balance between intellect and charm, it pays homage to Hollywood while reminding us that movies are not reality.  Movie characters may not really step off the screen and into your life, but you sure wish these ones would.

The love for the movies and the 30s comes through in woody allen's fourth wall breaking genre blending film The Purple Rose of Cairo. I am a sucker for happy endings so this film really was everything I hoped it could be EXCEPT the final act which dropped it from the 5 star rating I had in mind the first 70minutes

Woody's surreal portrait of bittersweet love and life of an innocent . 

REALLY LOVED IT . I DID
Tremendously imaginative. This is up with Crimes and Misdemeanour's and Zelig as one of Allen's best 80's films.
Probably the sweetest Allen film. Just not quite engaging enough.
Original, just that.
Yep it's perfect. One of Woody's best.

I loved this, and can see it potentially becoming a favourite of mine. It is at times very funny, very sweet, very romantic, and very sad. Mia Farrow is so likeable in it you can well imagine a film star coming down off screen and falling in love with her. I think it's perhaps the most complete of Woody Allen's films that don't star him, and one of his very best scripts.

"I just met a wonderful new man. He's fictional, but you can't have everything."
How did I survive so much of my life without Woody Allen?
A beautiful combination of wistful fantasy and existential emptiness.

One Allen film w/o himself (or one of his numerous doppelgangers), which is a clue that here is a subject that is finally larger than Allen: his love of movies, that he freely shares with movie fans everywhere.  So he takes one of the movie fan's most cherished desires (" ... I wish I could be there ... or that here was like there ...") and plays with it a little, the difference between reality and fantasy, and the grey in-between. Mia Farrow plays us, the fan, is our doppelganger, and the movies are: a) better than real life, and b) but not real life.  One of the better Allen films, akin to his early 'don't give a damn' stuff, before he became an auteur. Farrow's contented gazing at the screen is too brief to be iconic, but it should be ...
Depression-era fantasy, heavily-padded but with lovely moments!!

I never understood why people loved this film so much. I get why they would like it, but it never really resonated with me. Daniels and Farrow are great performers, but the film just wan't quite my thing. Although the beginning scenes I truly liked especially with Farrow and her abusive husband. But after the mid-point of the film, it felt...just meh. I don't know, just was a bit boring. It's still an okay film by Woody Allen. 3/5 or 6/10

At the time, this was the second film Woody Allen had made in which he didn't appear, but this was also showing how confident he was as a writer and director. It's a touching and gentle comic fantasy with an original idea at the centre, it's a homage to the cinema of old and the films Woody grew up with as well, it's a joy to watch. Set during the Great Depression in the 1930's, waitress Cecilia (Mia Farrow) gets by in her job and her loveless marriage to the abusive Monk (Danny Aiello). But Cecilia finds solace in going to the cinema, and there's a new film on called The Purple Rose of Cairo which she goes to see again and again, and it gets to the point where one of the characters in the film, Tom Baxter (Jeff Daniels), notices Cecilia, and comes out of the screen to be with her, leaving the characters on screen clueless as to whats happened. While Cecilia and Tom go out together, this strange occurence has the film's producer Raoul Hirsch (Alexander Cohen) and the star of the film Gil Shepherd (Daniels again), who plays Tom Baxter in the film, to come to New Jersey to sort the problem out, but then Cecilia falls for Gil as well. It's a very odd but magical romantic fantasy, cut from similar cloth to what Woody would use to make Midnight in Paris (2011), it's a wonder Woody hasn't tried stuff like this more often, as it brings out a nostalgic side to him that works on film, but it has laughs and poignancy too, like the old classics used to have.

The simplicity of this romantic comedy by Woody Allen is superb!  A depression-era woman (Mia Farrow) goes to see the movie of the film's title so many times, the leading actor (Jeff Daniels) walks off the screen to engage in a romantic affair.  The best parts are the remaining cast on the silver screen as they discuss the missing actor and argue about the necessity of the character.

Cecilia (Farrow) pretty much has nothing to live for-- she's stuck in a job she hates, she strapped with an abusive husband, and the Great Depression is causing her to live life the way she doesn't want to. For her, seeing the movies is the one bright spot in her life. Now the new movie in town, "The Purple Rose of Cairo" is her focus, and she goes to the film almost every day. To her surprise, a character in the movie, Tom Baxter (Daniels), takes notice, and jumps right out of the screen and into her life. The two begin an unlikely friendship and eventually fall in love, and this causes the movie to fail-- all of the other "actors" can't jump out of the scream, and they're worrying about what to do without the essential Tom. Considering it's becoming a box-office bomb, the actor who plays Tom (also Daniels) does anything he can to get his character back into the movie since his career is at stake. "The Purple Rose of Cairo" is a hilarious, classic Woody Allen that has the charms that his movies almost always deliver. But considering it was done during the same time as "Broadway Danny Rose" and "Hannah and Her Sisters", this film is often overlooked. Well, it shouldn't be. The idea for the film is ingenious, and nobody could have pulled it off better than Allen-- he creates a screenplay fitting for each and every character, and the banter going on the movie inside the movie is the highlight of the show. The screenplay is so clever and witty, and all of the actors, especially Daniels, pull off their silly characters and make it their own. This is one of my favorite Woody Allen films, and I hope others who see it feel the same way. "The Purple Rose of Cairo" is one of those bittersweet comedies that just get better with age. This is timeless Allen. Recommended.

A cute little fantasy hailed by many as Woody Allen's best...I'm not sure about that but it's a likeable film.

The story of a lovely woman escaping to the movies & one day the man of her dreams walks out of the screen to her.

Not entirely all convincing but it's a likeable with a fantastic dual performance by Jeff Daniels. There are many funny scenes & the film has a charm to it...

This is a wonderful movie.  Like his later film, Midnight in Paris, Allen again juxtaposes reality with the screen depiction of reality.  Like a surrealist dream, characters are marginally aware of their reality but even the "real" characters are just film characters.  It's a dream within a dream.  Mia Farrow is adorable.  Who could not love and feel for her character.  Just as Tom falls in love with her, so do we.  And in the end, despite the bittersweet, Cecilia is transported, albeit temporarily to happiness through the magic of the cinema.  There are so many metaphysical overtones.  There is the question of whether the characters exist when the projector is turned off.  Is our life too snuffed out into eternal darkness?
A cute little film about the nature of escapism well acted by Mia Farrow.

Woody Allen's "The Purple Rose of Cairo" is THE meta-romantic comedy classic. (I know thats a rather limited genre, but still) The picture is endlessly witty and charming. Mia Farrow and Jeff Daniels are wonderful here. Delightful and fun in every sense.
Jeff Daniels was such a sweetie and Mia was Mia. Liked the fantasy escapism vs. The Great Depression theme.

woody allen wrote and directed a wonderful fantasy in "the purple rose of cairo". it was almost impossible to wipe the smile off my face. though the ending is a bit of a downer, it feels very fitting. i absolutely love this movie. it's nothing short of a masterpiece, and definitely one of the best movies about movies ever made.
Charming and original, a great work by Woody Allen.

One Woody Allen's strangest films (up there with "Sleeper" from 1973), a poor waitress (another Mia Farrow vehicle!), is stuck in a worthless job and terrible marriage during the Great Depression. Her husband (Danny Aeillo) is a bum, who can't find work, is abusive physically and emotionally to Farrow, and fools around with other woman. After she finally is fired from her job, she retorts to a love addition to a film (not real) called "The Purple Rose of Cairo," to which the lead actor (Jeff Daniels) comes off the screen and takes her into his arms. The film, both the fictional and actual movie, gets weird from there. Certainly not one of Allen's best, but pretty funny at times and quite original. Quite inventive and nice use of black and white photography. Ending is sure a...shock! I will put it that way.
So brilliant and original!  And truly heartbreaking -- at least to me.  Another all-time favorite of the Wood-meister!
I have never seen such a perfect depiction of escapism and the romanticism of the silver screen.
Not just one, but 2 Jeff Danielses. A movie about how movies can transform our lives and dreams. And about choosing between what is really possible or living in a fantasy.
this movie is why I love movies

this film is one of woody's best, if not THE best. The innocence of the whole thing, the witty and charming script, the excellent acting. Its a type of tone and style of film not recreated except by Woody's own Midnight In Paris. this is a masterpiece.

A fictional character from a movie steps out into the "real world" to charm the pants off a woman with an unhappy marriage during the Great Depression. It is a wonderful, charming, funny film that's essentially about the magic of the movies. It's not Woody's funniest film but I had a smile plastered throughout a huge chunk of it. Jeff Daniels is terrific in a dual role and Woody Allen's muse, Mia Farrow, is also as strong as she's ever been. The final shot of the film is absolute perfection, IMO.

"The Purple Rose of Cairo" is a very unique fantasy film from the infamous Woody Allen and is also funny.  Set in the Great Depression, Mia Farrow is trapped in a dead end job and abusive marriage.  She goes to the cinema to dream and forget about the hardships of her life.  Eventually, the main character jumps off the screen and professes his love for her (!).  Then the actor who plays this character turns up.  Jeff Daniels had a lot of fun with this one.  Clever circumstances and another great film from Allen.

This is a lovely lovely film. It's got that charmingness to it that makes Woody Allen's films that aren't about Woody Allen so watchable. Very sweet but sad. Mia Farrow and both Jeff Danielses were great characters. I wish she'd been a bit more feisty though. Sigh.
Watch this movie, but don't watch any trailers or read any summaries beforehand. A really fun movie. Woody obviously derived Midnight In Paris from this.

The Purple Rose of Cairo is the best Woody Allen film made, and I say this without having seen many of his other films. I say this with full confidence to, and it would take a lot for something to surpass the precious Purple Rose of Cairo. Part of the reason I may love this movie is because it is too, about movies (well, part of it.) A poor women in the Great Depression finds movies her only escape and when one of the characters from a movie comes down from the screen to profess his love to her, that's when things start getting really interesting. This movie is humorous and ulmitatly left me in tears, with outstanding performances from Mia Farrow and Jeff Daniels.
A classic Woody Allen film. A movie about movies, and a pure joy to sit through.

The Purple Rose of Cairo is simply one of the great classics of modern cinema, mixing charm, style, depth and fantasy in a rare way. Woody Allen delivers a surrealist fantasy drama set in Great Depression-hit New York City in the 1930s, chronicling the life of a starstruck movie-obsessed woman, Cecilia (Farrow) who finds herself watching an eponymous film in which the main character, Tom (Daniels) comes to life, after which she is left in a complicated situation. First things first, the film is superbly directed. Whilst it balances elements of reality and fantasy, it never becomes cheesy or over-the-top, and the surrealist elements work perfectly. The film is pleasant to watch, and never feels heavy, yet it does not compromise its artistic integrity. It has the airy charm of a golden age Hollywood classic, yet it winds up as a contemporary picture which is fitting for modern-day audiences. Ultimately, the ending is thought-provoking, conveying the fact that whilst great films may inspire a person to dream of an ideal life, the reality is different and much harsher. All in all, a classy, well-directed film which features good performances from the leading roles, and which is successfully able to combine a pleasant plot with a great level of depth.
Mia is charming, but for isn't great

I am not a big fan of Woody Allen, but his recent "Midnight in Paris" reminded me of what I believe is his best film, "Purple Rose of Cairo." A thought-provoking look at movies as a means of escape, "Purple Rose" also addresses reality versus fantasy: how some viewers come to believe that the idealized romantic story on the screen (or on TV) is what their life ought to be like.  It's well-acted, clever, has some memorable lines, and has an ending you'll want to talk about.  "Purple Rose" should have gotten more attention when it came out, but it's well worth renting!
One of my all time favorites

I was on the fence about this one. The comedy isn't Allen's best but there are a few solid lines. And the drama involved didn't really grab me. But a day after i saw it, it kinda grew on me. The story is very sweet but it doesn't become sappy, which is always a tightrope in my opinion. That last shot with Mia Farrow made it worth the price of admission for me.
Interesting juxtaposition with Inglorious Bastards. Here cinema can improve your life but eventually you've got to come back to reality
Along with ANNIE HALL and HANNAH AND HER SISTERS, this is one of Allen's most consistently perfect films. A delight.
Don't know how it took me so long to see this, but I loved it!  An homage to movies and their fans.

Good Woody Allen flick with a nod to Hollywood's role in the Great Depression, perhaps especially for repressed and underloved housewives. It's a sweet film and one with an interesting theme seen somewhat frequently in film - is cinema better than reality?
luv it .. woody @ his finest ..

Light but charming Woody Allen film. 

Mia Farrow plays a put upon housewife with a lousy job and lousier husband. 

Her only escape from her Depression-era 1930s life is going to the local cinema where she idolises the stars of the day. Her life is stuck in a rut until one day her favourite actor (played by Jeff Daniels) walks out of the silver screen and into her life...

Not the landmark of Annie Hall or the sharp wit of Manhattan, but still a good 82 minutes about the love of film and it's power to take us to a better place.

It's clear Woody Allen knows how to pick and choose a strong cast.  Mia Farrow is irrefutably underrated; nobody has seemed to ever understand her potential, and I strongly feel that she is, in fact, one of the most outstanding Hollywood actresses from the latter half of the twentieth century.  Not only is she beautiful, her delivery is brilliant, and her chemistry with Jeff Daniels-who delivers just a slightly less powerful performance-is grand.

What more can I say about THE PURPLE ROSE OF CAIRO?  It isn't perfect, but it's very much close.  I'm talking about a sheer motion picture that represents the 1930s in perchance the utmost picturesque, vivid manner possible.  The writing is guaranteed pleasure for those who don't generally view film as a work of art, but for just about any cinephile watching this is bound to get a magical thrill similar to the kind a young child receives when he or she enters a candy shop.  In just two, simplistic words, it's magnificent.

read it all at themoviefreakblog.com
"I just met a wonderful new man. He's fictional but you can't have everything." brilliant quote

i love this movie, it is a myth built-up in a real world. A character coming out from a film, and in love with a woman in the real world - it sounds like a very romantic fiction, however, it's not that simple, it never be so "predictable" in Woody Allen's stories, his plots are always twisted, i guess that why i enjoy watching it so much!
Beautiful little movie that really tugs on your heart strings and chokes you up in the end that proves what the saying "Big gifts come in little packages" really mean.
Good movie, with a great performance from Farrow. The film-within-a-film seemed damn authentic! But *POSSIBLE SPOILER ALERT* it's kinda heartless the way Woody Allen treated his main character.

The Purple Rose of Cairo is the ultimate 30's comedy that was curiously made in the 80's. This jewel of film is a sample of beauty from the very first until the very last minute. It smells and feels like a 30's film, with all the charm, magic and innocence of that decade's films. It's full of magic, imagination, romance, joy, sadness, hope, dreams and ultimately tears combined with smiles. Although Mia Farrow was fantastic, Jeff Daniels owns completely this picture as far as the cast is concerned. Daniels played two characters: the "fictitious hero" and the "real villain", and he was wonderful in both performances. Danny Aiello was very good in his role of a male chauvinist and drunk husband. It's filled with memorable and unique moments. A film about life full of life. The ending was perfect and heartbreaking. If it had had a happy ending it would have been great too, but the way Allen did it was perhaps the most adequate choice. I didn't cry with in the ending but I wish I had. Perfectly written and directed by Woody Allen. An unfairly underrated masterpiece of the 80's.

One of the cutest BW films I have ever watched.

If you have never seen this movie I encourage you to get it and watch it. It is funny! It did not pass the "Anne" test, but to be fair, I had trouble staying awake, too. We walked five miles this morning and spent the day shopping at the Outlet Mall so it was probably impossible for any movie to keep us both awake.

I want to thank Faith for recommending this movie to me it was a great evening. Mia Farrow was wonderful.
Mia Farrow is pitch-perfect as a movie-loving waitress who wins the heart of a film star; he steps down from the big screen into real life to woo her. Allen's fondest homage to cinema.

Many movies have featured a character walking out of the screen or a real person joining the film, but "The Purple Rose" shows the implications of this.  The real-life actor is still walking around.  The other characters onscreen still have a movie to perform.  Original and funny.

Everyone watches movies as some means of escape. Escape of the everyday and life, but where do movies go when they want to escape?  This film has such a crazy concept that it has the potential to be incredibly cheesy, but Woody Allen executes it so perfectly that it's endlessly genius!
A bit too emotionally featherweight to be memorable, but still a clever, amusing, pleasant film.
it's simple, short, and sweet, making it all the more unique. 'the purple rose of cairo' is why we love the movies.
This overlooked Allen film is IMO one of his best!

Amazing movie!Woody Allen really knows how to direct movies.Nice premise,good acting,nice bitter ending.This movie is for everyone and even if you don't like romance movies,this could change your mind.

I remained cynical for a long time watching this, unconvinced that this was ever going to develop from it's silly premise into a satisfactory story. It did somehwat work it's magic on me half way through, mainly because I began to sense the warmth and pure love of cinema emanating from Allen's direction. Without him around for once, there's less manic energy but his presence is still felt in the dialogue and the characters thoughts concerning love, imagination and reality.

Woody's lovable ode to celluloid love affairs. It's hard not to be caught up in the magic of this love letter to love stories, and much like this year's "Midnight in Paris" I left feeling a sense of nostalgia for romanticism and charm. I enjoyed every of the 82 minutes.

Woody Allen amazed me again with a wonderful story. It is so hard to imagine the great creativity of this man. This movie wasn't as funny as the other Woody Allen movies I have watched, but I really liked the more romantic aspect of the movie. Mia Farrow is great and the story as a whole was very entertaining.

This is Woody sharing his love for cinema! A very sweet film with that fun touch mixed with the retro romance. I found it very original and entertaining, and the best part - it's short! It's just as long as it must be, but nothing extra is added.

It's based on pure fantasy put into the real world and it will leave you questioning: "But what if it acually happened?". Entertaining and fun with out being stupid, actually I found it really smart. It's also easy to spot Woody's hidden statements but the film it self is not particulary easy to predict. It's well crafted as well, showing some fine effects and that typical "overacted 30-50's way" of acting.

Even if it was original it remainded me in some ways of some of my favorites like "Cinema Paradiso" and "Groundhog Day", and that is surely a good thing. It's a film for lovers of cinema, and it still does the trick 25 years after the premiere. A playful film that left me with many smiles.

What would it be like if a character from one of your favourite movies leaped down from the screen into the real world? No, I'm not taking about 'Last Action Hero'. Here Woody Allen examines the relationship between film and it's audience and the power cinema can have on someone's life. The result is weird yet charming and at times hilarious, yet it's utterly unique and unlike most other movies I've seen. Jeff Daniels shows a lot of promise in one of his earlier roles and Mia Farrow is good as usual. Contains the sort of sharp humour you'd expect from a Woody Allen movie although he doesn't have a role this time, those looking for a few laughs won't be disappointed and may even shed a tear or two. I can totally see why Allen himself rates this as one of his best movies.
My favourite Woody Allen film by a long way. Brilliant plot device, clear message, even Mia Farrow isn't annoying. A jewel.
A sincere  love letter to the illusions, mirages, and myths and that up the movies.  It's one of Woody Allen's best films
The Purple Rose of Cairo directed by Woody Allen, starring Mia Farrow, Jeff Daniels. This is comedy-fantasy film, with beautiful plot, and something which cherishes audiences' moments, so joyfully.

The only way for some people to cope with the world is letting their minds wander. A lot of people fall in love with fiction. What if "fiction" fell in love with you? "The Purple Rose of Cairo" is one of Woody's savviest films. A romantic/ tragic comedy about seeking shelter in fantasy. May sound absurd, but is among the most insightful stories I've seen.

An enjoyable Woody Allen fantasy about a downtrodden Depression-era woman who finds true love with a movie character who escapes from the screen to be with her.  The real-world tale is fanciful, and it's perfectly counterpointed by the witty scenes involving the remaining movie players who are trapped onscreen, unable to continue their story.

A Woody Allen film about the magic of film and make-belief and the profound effect it can have on your everyday life. Mia Farrow is wonderful and pitiful as the abused housewife whose only joy comes from watching the stars on the silver screen. One day when she sees the same film for the 6th time, one of the characters walks off the screen and begins to woo her, causing the characters left on screen to be completely lost as to what to do. In Hollywood, studio bosses, and the actor portraying the character are none too pleased either.

The unexplained magical plot is somehow very easy to swallow, perhaps because the film characters respond in such a believable manner. But the true strength of the film lies in the bittersweet, tragicomic moments, at which Farrow excels.
would have been a better movie if the ending had been different. It causes you to question the whole movie. Is this girl just a crazie?

Our little Woody is still on fire here. (I refuse to apologize for such a good joke. Very well written. Very.) But don't worry! He's going to put himself out soon and make at least a decades worth of mediocre films! (or flicks as that fat bastard in jorts from New Jersey likes to say). 

An Open Letter To Woody Allen:

Dear Woody,

Do you know that you don't have to make a film every year? Or even every two years? Or three? You can go years without making another. And there are plenty of directors who've bowed out before dying. Hell! Kevin Smith is going to step away from the director's chair! Even he had the good sense to walk away! 

I can only assume that you have a problem. An addiction. Don't worry. I know a good methadone clinic. Or I know a dealer who'll sell you actual drugs. 

I know the good people who produce the television series Intervention, and that is us knocking on your door. I know you are reading this as you are a huge fan of my facebook movie reviews. And I know you're mad that I haven't actually written something for each film I've seen. WELL I KNOW WHEN I DON'T HAVE ANYTHING TO SAY. 

So you better let us in.

Sincerely,

Magnes

In my humble opinion this is the "sweetest" of all Woody Allen movies. The final scene....watching Mia Farrows face run the gamete of emotions all in one single frame was worthy of Academy attention which she didn't get for this picture, or for any other for that matter.  Bravo Mia, Woody.   4.5 stars.

Funny, charming and lighter than air, The Purple Rose of Cairo is the quintessential Woody Allen comedy. As per usual, the cast is a delight: a perfectly cast Mia Farrow, Jeff Daniels and Danny Aiello. The visuals and the music are enchanting; the ending, perfect. I actually preferred the similar Midnight in Paris but I thoroughly enjoyed Purple Rose as well.

Woody Allen's "The Purple Rose of Cairo" is THE meta-romantic comedy classic. (I know thats a rather limited genre, but still) The picture is endlessly witty and charming. Mia Farrow and Jeff Daniels are wonderful here. Delightful and fun in every sense.

I used to be a huge Woody Allen fan -- not so much these days. I recently watched The Purple Rose of Cairo for the first time, and generally speaking, I really enjoyed it. There were a few lagging sequences and it got a bit slow in the middle, par for the course with Allen, but it was a fluffy and nice enough way to spend an hour and a half. The premise itself, however, is something very close to perfection -- which might be why I was slightly disappointed when it didn't completely deliver in the way I had hoped. But I must ask, why is no one doing daring to tackle bizarre comedy like Woody Allen once did so well? Hell, even Allen has abandoned it. I say it needs a resurrection. Fewer Adam Sandler and Ashton Kutcher rom-com flops, and a few more bizarre comedies with bold and original premises, please.

I think this is one of Woody Allen's best films. The film is funny, warm hearted, crude, and great. TPROC sums up all the love and nastalgia Allen has for the cinema and it's interesting when he uses his muse (Mia Farrow) as the main character who is seen as a sad woman and goes to the movies to take away her own personal problems. Jeff Daniels is great as the iconic star who comes to life and wants to be with the Farrow character and embrace on a romantic relationship. This is a great picture.
Classic Woody Allen, surprisingly engaging despite a weird and silly plot. Don't let that comment fool you though, it's Allen at the top of his game. Definitely worth watching if you're an Allen fan.

"I'm a dramatic character. I need forward motion."

This one's a charmer until the end, which, though satisfying, is not "delightful"--not that it should be.  The entire cast is great, especially, of course, Daniels and Farrow.
No! I had such high hopes for Cecilia!
Writing is always  great in a woody allen film, funny film, and allen is the only filmmaker ive seen who can make a fake 1930's film feel and look it was made in the 30's...sad ending tho'
I really donno how many times do I hv to say this , byut woody allen is a genius ! every time he comes up with some sort of so innovative idea that u can't even think of ! xtra-ordinary.!
Alright we all have a lot of fun with the meta-escapism escapism-meta movie within a movie within a box within the original movie.  I guess that's my only point.

"The Purple Rose Of Cairo", one of Allen's best films, is a gorgeous romantic comedy that features two charming leads (the wonderful Mia Farrow and a very good, pre-"Dumb & Dumber" Jeff Daniels), excellent music and great jokes. A lovely film - that sort of movie that generates feelings of affection inside you.

One of Woody Allen's greatest films. If you think you love film, there is absolutely no reason you wouldn't love this one. It gets to the heart of why we love movies (or any art, for that matter) more beautifully, hysterically, and poignantly than almost anything I've ever seen. An absolute masterpiece.

Woody Allen's love letter to cinema is one of his career high points. The Purple Rose of Cairo is an utterly magical film, profoundly affecting and recognizable in all lovers of film. Mia Farrow's performance is excellent, and Jeff Daniels delivers in a very difficult dual-role, as an actor and his character. The supporting cast is excellent, as can be expected in a Woody Allen creation, especially Danny Aiello and Dianne Wiest, whose role is all too brief. Outstanding.

I must be getting old.
This Woody A movie is fantastic.
So enjoyable, brilliantly written and funny.
Very Clever!! Woody Allen said everything he wanted to say without appearing to be doing so. It was a great tribute to Buster Keaton's Sherlock Jr.

"I just met a wonderful new man.  He's fictional, but you can't have everything."

That wonderful line of dialogue from the magical pen of Woody Allen sums up the genius behind "The Purple Rose of Cairo".  "Cairo" is a funny, fun, clever and touching tale of an unhappy New Jersey housewife during the Great Depression who is swept away by a celluloid Prince Charming who comes into her life right off of the movie screen.  

What at first can sound like a shallow movie plot shows remarkable depth as the device is used merely as a vehicle to explore how sad reality can be.  Cecilia (the affecting Mia Farrow) spends her afternoons escaping her harsh married life in the town's movie house taking in the pictures.  When "The Purple Rose of Cairo" a picture about a dashing Egyptologist Tom Baxter played by fictional actor Gil Shephard (played by real actor Jeff Daniels) comes to town, Cecilia watches the movie several times until all of a sudden he breaks the fourth wall and notices Cecilia in the movie theater.  He steps off the screen and romances the down-on-her-luck Cecilia.

This of course wreaks havoc with the film and sets in motion a series of events that ultimately leads up to Cecilia having to make a potentially life-changing decision.  This film is well renown among Allen's films for how it unfolds and it does so brilliantly and without compromise and without sacrificing the film's tone.  

The performances, particularly Farrow, were spot on, but "Cairo"'s biggest achievement is its ability to take such a fantastical plot point (remember how poorly "The Last Action Hero" did it?) and make it work so beautifully.  

"Purple Rose of Cairo" ranks among Woody Allen's best and is one of his most underappreciated classics.

Another amazing film by Woody Allen.  I can see why this would be his favorite.  It fully covers his ideas on love, but at the same time is really charming.  Jeff Daniels was great as Tom Baxter, an explorer from a movie called The Purple Rose of Cairo, who somehow sees a woman in the audience and falls in love with her so much that he decides to leave his film and enter the real world to be with her.  Cecilia isn't loved by her husband and seems to only have one friend, so when Tom takes her away she leaves without a second thought.  Yeah, a man strangely exits the screen, but she is lonely and she has been in love with him since the first time she saw the movie.  Woody Allen continues the story line between the two while answering questions about the two worlds colliding without ever taking a break.  I loved when Tom goes into the brothel and has no idea what is happening.  Even though there are many charming and happy moments throughout the film I always felt an underlying sense of sadness.  She is finding new love, but at the same time she is still married to the jerk who cheats right in front of her.  This broken marriage is constantly stopping her from showing her true love to a man who wants nothing except her love.  It is strange to be screaming "cheat on the husband!" but that's what was going on.  Allen creates such a great connection to Cecilia that we care a great deal about every little choice she will make.  Perhaps because we watch movies to escape our lives, and Cecilia is the same way and she has the opportunity that we have always wanted.

**SPOILERS**

Of course, the movie ends with Woody Allen keeping to his true self and his views on love.  Cecilia decides that she wants the actor, Gil Shepherd, instead of his character, Tom, simply because he is real.  She thinks she has gone completely insane falling for a fictional character.  But she does believe that true love exists.  Unfortunately, Gil was just playing her so that he could get his character to go back on screen.  It's such a heartbreaking revelation in the film, but the ending is perfect with Cecilia sitting in the theater watching the famous scene "heaven, I'm in heaven" by Ginger and Fred, and she slowly gets a smile on her face.  According to Allen, love does not last, it's only for movies.  If she wanted true happiness she should have stayed in the film with Tom, or else she can go back to reality where the husband beats and cheats on her and the actor lies about loving her.
This film deals about searching for happiness and the story is told in a unique way.

It's awfully schmaltzy, and doesn't quite meet its potential as far as emotional punch goes, but The Purple Rose of Cairo is one of Woody's best; a fantasy that glorifies the magic (and manipulative tendencies) of film.  Certainly worth watching.

k yeah jeff daniels was hot!
such a fun movie. loved it
It would have been perfect to me if it wasn't for Mia Fuckin' Farrow.

Certainly a bold departure for Woody Allen, The Purple Rose of Cairo is spellbinding fantasy tale that is both funny and romantic and benefits from its wonderful cast, mainly Farrow and Daniels, and is a near-perfect homage to old-fashioned romance movies and to movies in general. Only Woody Allen could have pulled off all the feats this film achieves.

Although Woody Allen can hardly escape the self-aware movie, he does it sublimely when the focus is more inventive than as a parody (and it helps this time that he didn't cast himself as the lead -- or at all).  Maybe it's a film-fan-only kind of movie, but then again any great work of art is only great when the person consuming it can properly comprehend it.

My favorite Woody Allen film.  Reportedly one of his personal favorites, as well.  The fantasy found within the plot augments the maeger reality of the film's setting and the main character's harsh surroundings, making the no-nonsense ending even more of a jolt when it arrives.

I always find Allen intellectualism a bit cold, even here (and the same goes for his frankly cringing manic, depressive, compulsive, passive-aggressive characters): still, on of his best, thanks to metafilm nostalgia and the heartshredding tragedy impending over a (woefully) forgotten miracle of a movie.

Plot:

Perhaps the least appreciated of Allen's great films, The Purple Rose of Cairo, is arguably his most playful, albeit direct, outing. Set in New Jersey during the great depression of the 1930's, Mia Farrow plays Cecilia, a film aficionado and broken housewife. Recently, her marriage has since turned into a considerable disaster and she finds herself in frequent disagreement with her out-of-work, abusive, and even womanizing husband, Monk (Danny Aiello). 

Too afraid to be on her own, she naturally finds escape at the local cinema where she sits upon hours in admiration of the actors on screen and the lives in which their characters live. When the theater first features the film entitled The Purple Rose of Cario, Cecilia finds herself enamored by the film and its subsequent character, Tom Baxter (Jeff Daniels).  The following day while at work as a waitress, she finds herself distracted from the mere memory of the feature and due to the nature of her reverie is there upon fired for her demeanor. She later frequents the film over and again and it is not until the happening of one her later viewings, perhaps the sixth time over, that her presence attracts the attention of Tom Baxter, causing him to come off-screen and appear before her and all others in the theater.

As he confesses his attraction toward her, together the two run off as the audience and too the characters on screen (as if suddenly viable actors taking part in play) remain caught in panic and awe. Word soon spreads that a character in a feature film has walked off screen, discovering the real-world. Expectedly the news spreads quickly to ears of the film's producer, Raoul Hirsch, and the actor who portrays Tom Baxter, Gil Shepherd (Jeff Daniels). Mr. Hirsch's objective here is to stop the mass running of his picture to cease any further occurrences that share semblance and potential lawsuits. Gil Shepherd finds himself frightened at the thought of losing his growing popularity due to what crimes he believes the character he created, his essential double for all intensive purposes, may be out committing.

Cecelia You're Breaking My Heart:

Mia Farrow's interpretation of Cecilia is simply charming. It is with such perfection that she plays the role of this lonely, naïve romantic in search of change. Her lamenting disposition and reserved attitude, together, truly make her irresistible to any viewer and impossible for one not to feel sympathetic toward her plight.

Jeff Daniels does as well a marvelous job as both Tom Baxter and Gil Shepherd. He very well may be amongst Hollywood's underrated.

Film as a World of its Own:

The Purple Rose of Cairo presents yet another interesting aspect in the sense that Allen depicts the world on the theater screen as a world entirely of its own; and it is! Cecelia mentions over and again her desire for a world similar to the depictions on screen and it is with a high degree of craft that Allen creates that so sought after world. The scene in the picture itself, when Tom Baxter leaves, can no longer move forward or backward, but must remain in place. The characters however are free to move about, discuss at will topics of interest, as well as see outwardly, beyond the screen, into the theater. These characters on screen are alive, disturbed even. Their world of routine has since been interrupted and they are left in a state of restlessness and wait for there is nothing more they desire than to continue their life of pattern. One character even mentions excitedly how he is a "dramatic character" and needs "forward motion" while another mentions the fear he has of the screen going "black". In their impatience others pass time arbitrarily by poking jokes at the audience. As a whole these sequences make for brilliant satire that only Allen could write.

Tom Baxter leaves the picture and enters the real-world where he remains no longer a victim of repetitiveness. Moviegoers, however enthusiastic, wish to enter the very world of a Hollywood picture in the hope of escaping theirs.

The two worlds do exist and perhaps are separate equals, but after all, what is a life without the movies? What is a life without wanting to or even having an escape, even if only for a little while?

Love, Actually:

What else Purple Rose so genuinely explores is the unrequited love one may share for a fictional character; be that of literature, film, or even our very own imaginative perception of those so in which living life surrounds us with to a great abundance. Cecilia found herself enthralled by the character Tom Baxter even before he took his first steps off-screen. His charm, his romanticism, looks and perfections that captivated her so, all of course translated to the real-world. However, his limited knowledge of the living-world, what is past and now, as well as being only capable of what has been written into his character, hinders Tom Baxter from certain human emotions. Also, as aforementioned, he, Tom Baxter, is in practical sense, fictional.

One has to wonder if it is the artist whom they love or his creation. It is here in Allen's piece that Cecilia falls too in deep affection toward the actor who portrays Tom Baxter. He is certainly a man of a great many faults no doubt, but an artist no less and more importantly, the man who gave life to Tom Baxter. It is such that Cecilia finds herself amidst the grand decision of choosing reality or fantasy for her ultimate happiness.

One Sentence Summary:

The Purple Rose of Cairo is a fantastic, probing piece of cinema in which, through comedic, romantic tones, great acting and of course music, leaves the viewer appreciating cinema that much more than what was once before.

Movies have always been used as a form of escapism, especially when times are tough (such as during the Great Depression), but what happens when the movies themselves desire escape?  That's what happens in Woody Allen's "The Purple Rose of Cairo", Allen's tribute to the golden age of cinema.  The film is indeed appropriately set smackdab in the middle of the Great Depression, where lonely Cecilia struggles hard to make ends meet.  Inbetween slaving as a waitress in a diner and taking care of her domineering and abusive husband (the excellently creepy Danny Aiello), she frequents the local movie house.  She must go there often as she's on a first name basis with all the employees.  Sure, during the day her life may suck, but for a few hours each week, she can be transported off to exotic locations and expensive night clubs, experiencing the fleeting affairs and romances of beautiful movie stars.  She especially enjoys the new film, "The Purple Rose of Cairo", taking in several matinees.  One character, the "aww shucks", all around good guy and egyptologist, Tom Baxter (Jeff Daniels), especially catches her eye.  She apparently also catches his eye, as one day he turns to her and begins speaking to her from up on the screen.  Moments later, he steps down off the screen and the two run off together, bringing scene to a halt.  The characters in the movie don't know what to do without Tom there, and so just sit and wait for him to return, much to the chagrin of the audience in attendance (they begin to heckle the screen, and the people in the movie begin to heckle the members of the audience in return).  Word quickly spreads of this strange phenomenon and soon the town is bustling with hollywood agents looking to put an end to the "bad publicity".  Meanwhile, Cecilia and Tom grow acquainted and of course like any old time movie character, Tom almost immediately proclaims his love for her.  Cecilia seems more concerned with just catching her breath after all the supernatural goings on, but she's entirely sympathetic to the idea.  Much like her fantasies of leaving her husband, her fantasies of running off with Tom seem like they are so very possible.  The craziness only heightens when the actor who portrayed Tom Baxter in the movie, Gil Shepherd, comes to town to try and save his career in hollywood (just suppose this living incarnation of his performance commits some crime or "rapes some woman", as his agents so often remind him).  He too, meets and becomes attracted to Cecilia, who is then caught in a sort of love triangle between a movie star and his character.  It's a quaint little film that still manages to give us a bit of melancholy near the end, as per Allen's more serious films.  The Tom Baxter character is the stand in for Woody this time, fulfilling Woody's usual role of being an outsider looking in (or is it an insider looking out?).  He makes no bones about his feelings about anything: love, religion, society.  The character is the perfect man as invisioned by Woody.  And yet, he's also a very apt tribute to the great film characters of the early days of cinema.  In fact, the Purple Rose of Cairo is a love letter to the golden age of film.  The care put forth into creating a 1930s film, from the lighting and film type, to the music and make up, it all looks authentic.  The Purple Rose of Cairo is a film that aims small, but hits big.

The movie is great, it has a wonderful script and Jeff Daniels is brilliant, as is the rest of the supporting cast. I just couldn't get over how much I dislike Mia Farrow, particularly in this kind of role.
Good lord, will he ever make a movie that doesn't make me want to throw myself off a bridge?
If the Last Action Hero were a Romantic Comedy.

I realize i'm not really a fan of these Woody Allen films that are more on straight up comedy like this and broadway danny rose. I'm a huge fan though of his somehow more dramatic films like Manhattan, Husbands and Wives, Crimes & Misdemeanors etc.

An absolutely wonderful Woody Allen movie. This is one of his lightest, friendliest movies. The premise of the story (which won the Golden Globe for Best Screenplay) is simple and delightful: a troubled woman living during the Great Depression goes to see a movie so often that one of the characters notices her and steps out of the movie and into real life to meet her. The story has some really funny and inventive developments from there. The dialogue is frequently hilarious. Mia Farrow gives the best performance I've seen from her so far, as a woman who is delicate and timid but lovable. Jeff Daniels is fantastic as both the movie character she meets and the actor who played that character. The scenes with that character are great, because he only understands the simple romantic world of his movie and has trouble grasping the real world he finds himself in. Danny Aiello is suitably loutish as Farrow's abusive husband, and Dianne Wiest has an amusing bit part as a prostitute. The movie-within-the-movie is a convincing re-creation of the style of 1930s Hollywood pictures. The only problem with the movie is that it lacks a satisfactory ending. Overall, though, this is one of Allen's best.
The only thing better than Jeff Daniels starring in a Woody Allen movie is *two* Jeff Daniels starring in a Woody Allen movie.
This is classically romantic Allen. Original, charming, magical and real. A paradoxical filmic oasis.

Beautiful, imaginative, hilarious, bittersweet, clever, romantic. One of Woody Allen's very best.

I am in love with this great guy - he is imaginary - but you can't have everything
Lots of fun. The ending's kind of depressing but at the same time entirely appropriate and perfect for the film. Jeff Daniels is great.

Woody Allen described the gem Purple Rose of Cairo as his favorite piece of work, and one can clearly see why. The characters are living breathing portraits of the famed rom-com expert, as well as the overall premise and moral. His best work? I wouldn't say so. But there's no denying the beauty that's captured here.
Jeff Daniels reminded me of a younger Jason Segel. His performance in Purple Rose of Cairo, a dual role as on-screen persona Tom Baxter and real-life actor Gil Shepard, is one of the best of his career. Mia Farrow delivers a stealthy feat when it came to acting out a female byproduct of an Allen oddball. Dianne Wiest also sparkled whenever she came on the screen.
The Purple Rose of Cairo may damn well be the darkest Woody flick to date. It's a story of romantic tragedy that was never meant to be from the get-go, and the foolish woman who fell for it all. Though Allen's portrayal of females in film has been and always will be one of his strongest features. Even with something so blatantly personal there's never been a more creative atmosphere than what takes place in Cairo.
The humor is rather bland, but per usual it takes a while to settle in your stomach. The Purple Rose of Cairo is as quirky as the man behind the camera is, along with a fantastic score from Dick Hyman that adds to a triumph that's on the outside nothing short of perfect. Woody Allen strings together the perfect cliché, in a movie that's truly stranger than fiction.

90% Critics liked it

this film has all the charm and quirkiness of Woody Allen's style, it just seems to suffer from a lack of Woody Allen.  the acting honestly isn't all that great--Farrow and Daniels are average at best.  the writing unsurprisingly is very clever, however, and even if the dialogue isn't always top-notch, the storytelling certainly is.  a great homage to classic film and an astute look at fantastical romance vs. harsh reality.  maybe not one of Allen's more memorable films, but it certainly is uniquely his.
